thread.title: Emojis aren't just for Vladimir Putin, they're for other pollies too
thread.title_full: Emojis aren't just for Vladimir Putin, they're for other pollies too

author: canberratimes.com.au
title: Emojis aren't just for Vladimir Putin, they're for other pollies too
text:

Emoji diplomacy: red faces all round Julie Bishop uses a red-face man emoji to describe Vladimir Putin, and senate estimates wants to know why.
PT2M22S 620 349 Senate estimates hearings are notorious for getting bogged down in detail that no one cares about.
But ears pricked up in Canberra this week when Labor's Penny Wong started quizzing Foreign Affairs officials about Julie Bishop's use of emojis .
The Foreign Affairs Minister is an enthusiastic user of emojis - the small pictures (often of facial expressions) that are used to convey a quick message in things like texts, tweets and Facebook posts.
Given this, news website Buzzfeed conducted an interview with Bishop earlier this year in which all her answers were in emoji.
Advertisement On Thursday during estimates, Wong wanted to know what Bishop meant when she described Russian President Vladimir Putin with a red frowny​ face.
"What is the diplomatic message?" Wong asked, as flummoxed officials replied they would take the question on notice (code for: we have no idea).
But Putin isn't the only politician who can be expressed in emoji, as these local examples created by the team at Fairfax Media show:
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is on top. He has the toppest​ job in the country, a new spare harbour front mansion and the opinion polls LOVE him.
Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop is never far from her iPhone, where she emojis the world. Not that the death stare master needs help expressing herself.
Labor leader Bill Shorten is giving his best impersonation of Grumpy Cat. The opinion polls most definitely do not love him.
Treasurer Scott Morrison is the nation's new money man and coiner of three-word slogans. He wants you to work, save, invest.
Member for Warringah Tony Abbott is processing a lot of stuff right now.
Labor Senate leader Penny Wong is sleuthing. She's had a huge week working out what happened to *that* marble table and what an unhappy face means.
Immigration Minister Peter Dutton is saying as little as possible. He has the immigration portfolio!
Outgoing MP Joe Hockey is enjoying a cigar. Now that he's quit Parliament he has more time for a puff.
Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese is enjoying the fact that he isn't leader in these rocky times. And that a micro-brewery has named a corn ale beer in his honour .
Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce is puce in the face. This always happens during question time.
Liberal senator Eric Abetz is angry about a variety of things. From losing his ministerial gig to losing Abbott as PM and a looming same-sex marriage plebiscite, he is one cranky cookie.
Assistant Minister for Innovation Wyatt Roy is on the frontbench at an age when most kids are still wondering what they want to be when they grown up.
Attorney-General George Brandis is no longer the Minister for Arts. But everyone knows he's still the most cultured guy around.
Palmer United leader Clive Palmer is still turning up to Parliament occasionally.
